info.name: Performance Testing v1.1 Cloud
info.description:
This performance test suite evaluates the responsiveness and efficiency of API endpoints to ensure they comply with defined business performance criteria.

### Scope of Tests

The suite covers the following test categories:

- **Response Status Codes**
    
    Verifies that the correct HTTP status codes (e.g., 200, 400, 401, 404, 500) are returned according to the request context.
    
- **Response Time Validation**  
    
    Measures the time taken for APIs to respond under typical and peak load conditions. Ensures endpoints consistently meet predefined response time thresholds (e.g., <300ms for standard queries).
    

This suite is intended for CI/CD integration and supports environment-specific testing (e.g., development, staging) via Postman environments and variable configurations. Each test case is stateless and idempotent, ensuring consistent results across repeated executions.

## Setup Instructions

### Collection Configuration

- **Collection Variables**
    
    Store common configuration valuesâ€”such as base URLs and auth tokensâ€”at the collection level to enable reuse and centralized management.
    
- **Environment Requirements**
    
    A Postman environment must be selected before execution. This environment supplies dynamic values like environment-specific URLs and credentials.
    
- **Collection-Level Pre-request Scripts**
    
    Define global setup logic (e.g., timestamp generation, authentication headers) that executes before each request for consistent initialization.
    
- **Folder-Level Pre-request Scripts**
    
    Use folder-scoped scripts for modular setup logic such as test data creation, parameter configuration, or group-specific headers.
    
- **Automated Functional Assertions**
    
    Each request includes tests to validate HTTP status codes, response payload structure, and headers.
    

**Note:** Ensure a valid environment is selected and all necessary variables are properly configured prior to running the test suite.

## Database

We are using the [BigDemo_Magnus](https://jtlgmbh-my.sharepoint.com/:u:/g/personal/thomas_hoffmann_jtl-software_com/EfqpyN76rThPklDduV1hueMBHd_pPBYyV7YYe4rcoWHpgQ?e=hX8gJb) database (around 20 GB) for the perfromance tests.

Ensure that you have installed the database and register the app in this DB.

Use the app registration data (app-sersion, app-id, api-key) to build your own environment.

## Creating a New Environment

Create a new Postman environment with the following key-value pairs:

| Key | Description |
| --- | --- |
| `tenantName` | Your database name (e.g., `eazybusiness, mandant_1, ...`) |
| `apiKey` | The API key from your app registration |
| `appID` | The App ID from your app registration |
| `appVersion` | The version of your registered app |
| `runAsUser` | User ID to execute as (default: `1`) |
| `baseURL` | Base URL of your REST API instance (default: `http://localhost:5883`) |
| `authorizationValue` | Use the format `Wawi {{apiKey}}` (no backticks) |
| `expectedMaxAmountOfCustomers` | The expected number of customers in your database |
| `expectedMaxAmountOfArticles` | The expected number of articles in your database |

ðŸ’¡ **Hint:** You can duplicate an existing environment and update the values as needed. Donâ€™t forget to rename the copied environment to avoid confusion.

## Script Details

### Pre-request Script

This script sets required headers for each request, such as:

- `x-apiVersion`
    
- `x-AppId`
    
- _(and other custom headers)_
    

It also checks if all required variables (environment, collection) are setup-ed.

### Test (Post-request) Script

## Contribute

Follow the instruction of the [how to contribute](https://confluence.jtl-software.de/spaces/~THoffmann/pages/273687352/How+to+contribute) documentation.

item.description:
### **Create Article (minimal data)**

- **Method:** `POST`
    
- **Endpoint:** `baseUrl/items?disableAutomaticWorkflows=true`
    
- **Purpose:** Creates a new article with essential fields such as `Name`, `SKU`, `Description`, and tax/shipping identifiers.
    
- **Performance Use Case:** Used in loops to simulate high-volume insert operations. A pre-request script increments a SKU value and halts execution when `createMaxItemCount` is reached.
    
- **Dynamic Fields:**
    
    - `Name` is randomized.
        
    - `SKU` is timestamp-based with a random integer suffix.
        
- **Automation Logic:**
    
    - Ensures environment variable `createMaxItemCount` is set.
        
    - Automatically increases `createCurrentItemCount` for each call.
        
    - Skips further creation once the max count is reached.

query.description: A search key word which is using many important item identificators. For more info see documentation or the configuration in the search in items in JTL-Wawi.
Id of the category.
Id of one of the item manufacturers.
Id of one the parent item.
The date last changes were made to the item.
The ID of the sales channel on which this item is active.
Number of the page of items to fetch.
Size of the page that is specified by `pageNumber`.

item.description:
### **Iterate all pages of articles**

- **Method:** `GET`
    
- **Endpoint:** `baseUrl/items?pageNumber={{pageNumber}}`
    
- **Purpose:** Fetches articles page-by-page to test pagination performance.
    
- **Performance Use Case:** Evaluates how the API handles page traversal and batch reading across large datasets.
    
- **Dynamic Behavior:**
    
    - Uses `hasNextPage` and `totalPages` to control loop continuation.
        
    - Adjusts `pageNumber` automatically.
        
- **Pre-request Logic:**
    
    - Starts from a configurable page (`defaultStartPageNumber`).
        
    - Skips request if `hasNextPage` is false.
This folder contains requests related to managing article records in the system. It is structured into two subfolders based on HTTP methods.

exec: // validate that all required variables are setup-ed
pm.expect(pm.environment.get(item), `Collection Pre-Request: Environment variable ${item} not set`).to.not.be.undefined;
pm.expect(pm.environment.get(item), `Collection Pre-Request: Environment variable ${item} is empty`).to.not.be.empty;
